ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: Ben Hayes and Marlyse Druguid offered amazing support for the course.
Question 7: The learning material for the field trips was not well organized and didn't paint a clear picture of what we were supposed to be getting out of them.

Ann is an amazing instructor who really cares about the students. She tried to put as many field trips in as possible, encouraged us to think critically about the material and always managed to make her class really fun. This was one of my favorite classes.

Learning the concepts from a lecture based powerpoint format was not conducive to my learning style. There was a lot of text on the slides that made lecture seem as if I was reading a textbook. I could have really benefitted from a separate discussion section to go over the broad concepts from each lecture. I found lectures hard to follow and unorganized. There were a lot of detailed facts that were introduced, which took away from the big picture that I was supposed to take away from each lecture. I also could have benefitted from review questions after each lecture.
Favorite class of my semester!
Content was interesting, the lecture-from-powerpoint format is hard for me.

Question 10: More than any other instructor I have encountered at FES, Ann Camp takes interest that students are learning the material and thinking critically about the material would be applied in their future work.

This class will give you an excellent conceptual understanding on forests, their development and dynamics that affect them. The field trips are integral and well run and Ann choses readings that explain and provide discussion on the topics.
Loved this course!

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: The passion of the instructor. The diversity of students in the class (MEM vs. MESc MFS students). Incredible amount of information packed into one semester.
The field trips are amazing! It is a great opportunity to get out and see how concepts are represented in reality. I really learned a lot from the field trips and enjoyed them a lot.

Excellent field trips, which serve multiple, awesome functions: getting to know the forests as amazing resources Yale has to offer, getting to know your colleagues, and having the opportunity to devise your own lens for applying classroom theory to real settings. Presentations took a long time (3 weeks of class meetings) but were worth it since our classmates did interesting work-- it's not often that we get to share for 10 minutes and was a cool opportunity to learn about one another's work.
Student presentations and projects

I'd say the personal project (and the fact that we could do an annotatedd bibliography - it forced you to read a lot of scientific papers about a topic of your interest), Ann's humor and the philosophical questions that were raised.
Professor Camp's lectures; student presentations.

The organization of the class: the material built on the past topics in a logical way. The field trips really complemented and drove home the course material. The student presentations were really fascinating and varied at the end.

The field trips were very helpful in visualizing the concepts introduced in class. I don't think I would have understood most of the concepts without the field trips. The presentation was a good opportunity to explore a topic of interest that related to concepts introduced in class. However the big emphasis on timing of the presentation took away from other more essential presentation skills.
Excellent, well organized lecture and reading materials. Her wealth of knowledge and experience shines through to her students.
Field trip w Tom Wessels.
I liked the discussions, field trips, student presentations.

Field trips were the best aspects. They quickly and succinctly synthesized all the classroom lessons. The readings are also a major value of this course. They were consistently the best and most interesting readings I had this semester.

I really enjoyed the readings and presentations. The class builds on itself well and provides a very thorough overview of the evolution of knowledge and literature related to stand dynamics. Ann is also very knowledgeable and funny.
The field trips, class presentations, and Ann's instruction.
Class discussion was always great. Ann does a great job organizing the material and making it interesting.
Ann is an excellent lecturer, and the field trips were extremely informative.
The professor, the materials and the structure of the course.
Field trips
I really enjoyed the field trips-- it wasn't until I saw the forests in real life that I actually understood the concepts!

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: The tests are very applied and do not align with what we are taught and discuss in class. I loved this class, but think the we could be better prepared for the exams.
Organization of learning material for field trips
Not just read the slides, but also bring practical examples. Slides are full of text and sometimes confusing, making the class not interesting at all.
Some papers were less relevant I feel.
It would be great to have a "wrap-up" summary class - to put all the concepts together in the end.

Lectures need to be reformatted. The powerpoints were rich with text and hard to follow. The paper discussions seemed to be diverge from the paper's main points. I think to improve discussions email the discussion questions for each paper before class so students have time to think about them. I found the pace of lectures to be extremely fast paced and it was difficult to grasp the concepts during class time. An overview slide from the previous lecture would be helpful. An overview slide of what is going to be discussed at the beginning of every class section would also be helpful. There was also little instruction given as to how to format the annotated bibliography and there were no student produced examples provided as a resource. The organization of the course schedule was often confusing. The resources on the classesv2 website often didn't match the schedule and I often found myself reading the wrong papers for class. Sometimes unfair that students who did not have a class before or after stands got extra time to work on the final and midterm. If the final is 2 hours long then all students should have 2 hours to complete the final not 2 - 3. Be mindful that some students have back to back finals during exam week.
It was weird, after the midterm, how there were only a few lectures before it was three straight weeks of student presentations. It felt like things lost momentum before the final exam.
I wonder if there are ways to discuss content from student presentations in class, rather than just presenting them and being done. Felt a little disjointed.
My only major suggestion is to add more field trips.
Some of the course materials seem a little dated, such as the power point slides. It was hard to know if all of the information was the most up to date (I think it was but, I'm not sure).
I would have loved more time in the field! A bit more walking through how Ann would make management decisions- maybe some case studies- would have been useful.
I don't think this course needs significant improve.
Make us more accountable for the readings by forcing us to identify questions on Dropbox prior to class.

Anne's lectures are good, but I had trouble seeing how the different concepts linked together and how that applies to the real world. I felt like there was a disconnect between different lectures and then between the lectures and the exams.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: There is no lab section.
Course lectures closely followed the theme of discussions and field trips
I think it was really good, the only thing we should watch out is that when we discuss the readings we don't digress too much from the paper.
Definitely; the best linked lecture/lab combination I've had at FES.
N/A but needs a discussion section. Maybe provide an optional discussion section.
The discussions were my favorite classes. Just be sure to have done the class readings!!
I really enjoyed the discussion sessions, they helped me understand the literature on which the lectures were based. They also had a good balance of management and science.
Discussions on the readings were great and very student run.
Na

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: This course is very useful to my overall program.

This is a wonderful class the forms the base of my masters focus. I had little background in this subject before taking the class, and it was perfect for me to build that foundation of knowledge that I will need in the future.
Fits great, really happy I took it.
Concepts introduced will be useful in understanding how to manage forests.
As an MF, it was perhaps the most quintessential course of my graduate career. Natural forest processes lie at the heart of all management decision making.
It's foundational to my MF curriculum.

Absolutely CRUCIAL for any MF or aspiring MF! A great introduction to the program. Highly suggested for the first semester at Yale. Also a great course for any non-MF that's interested in taking a forestry course while at Yale.
This course is the foundation of my program. As an M.F. student it is the ideal way to begin my course of study.
I am not an MF but it was an interesting and useful course for MEM's and others interested in learning more about the foundation of forest stand dynamics.
It was a great basis for the beginning of the MF program.
I am an MF student and stand dynamics is an important foundational class for my curriculum.
It is a must take class as an mf. Loved the personal stories of Ann and the historical view of forestry was phenomenal. An incredible course to launch my mf degree.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: Because it is a requirement and I am very interested in the topic.
It was a good fit for the sort of research I'm interested in
It's a prerequisite for another class - Management of Protected Areas
To manage forests you need a good understanding of the ecology behind it. Doing MF, I felt this was a necessary and good choice.
Wanted to understand the development of forests to make myself a better forest manager in the future.
It looked cool, and aligned with my interests, and was recommended for my degree, MF.
Because I am really interested in knowing natural systems.
Interesting, and required.
Required for my degree (though you wouldn't have to twist my arm to do it again).
I'm an M.F. student and this is a paramount course.
To give me basic knowledge on forests and understanding of that ecosystem.
I heard it was everyone's favorite course!
Learn about ecosystem development and cycles

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes!
The knowledge I gained exceeded my expectations.
Yes
The course was more management focused than I was hoping, but I still learned a lot
Overall, yes.
Yes, definitely.
Yes
I learned a lot by the end of the course, but did not feel like I was learning throughout the semester.
Yes!
Exceeded!
yes
Yes and more. I couldn't be more excited to pursue the MF track after taking this course. I want more Ann Camp classes!

Yes, certainly. I now look at trees and forests in completely different way--both academically and casually. Ann did a tremendous job making the content fun and relevant to a wide range of students. From presentations, field trips and discussion, the class was well thought out and delivered.
Yes.
Yes! Very solid understanding on the factors that shape and affect forests.
Yes. I gained a working understanding of forest stand dynamics both through conceptual learning and field trips.
Yes!

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: N/A

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: If you are truly interested in stand and forest dynamics, take this class. It is a lot of work, but really a great class.
Keep up with the extra readings, you will get a lot more out of the class material that way.
Readings are fun and interesting; this course is well-suited to be paired with Plant Hydraulics. Field trips are awesome!
Remember the names of the authors of the papers and in one sentence what the papers talked about. She WILL test you on that and not only the content.
Go on 'stands walks' to solidify what you learn in class!
Almost an essential course for any MF, but learning the concepts in this class is difficult and confusing.
Study early and often
Take it! A wonderful and interesting course!
Outline the readings briefly so you can refer to them by author.

Stay on top of the readings. Not only do they make the lecture material interesting, but they're quite interesting in their own right. A walk in the woods will never be the same after taking this course!

This class will change the way you look at trees and a forest. It is an ideal balance of ecology and ecosystem management that is relevant to everyone from foresters to hikers. I encourage you to ask questions during class and go see Ann in office hours. She makes a lot of time for students and you will get even more out of the class.
This is a wonderful course, with a great professor. The slides have a lot of information on them but that will come in handy when you study for the tests.
Take it!
Ann is simply amazing. Go on as many field trips as you can. They help solidify the information!
